I'm not one of those types of people to replay video games. I play 'em once, and I'm done. That's all that I need to do. On occasion, if a game is really good, I'll go back to it once or twice. Maybe. What I don't do--what I absolutely do not DO... is put two hundred and eighteen hours into a game, which at present, is exactly what I've done with Dragon Age: Origins.

It is, suffice it to say, very much an exception to the rule, and I can't entirely be sure why. The plot's bog-standard fantasy fare (and worse, it requires that you be friendly to elves, who are the single worst race that has ever (not) existed, and every single one of them deserve to die; I think you and I can both agree that elves are, in fact, lazy scumbags who probably eat babies; I am highly offended at having to play a game as if I am, in fact, a friend of elves, because everyone knows they're horrible people responsible for all the world's problems, with their high and mighty 'we were so immortal and cool and awesome and amazing and perfect but you puny humans destroyed us' well you know what, you punks? if we destroyed you, maybe you just sucked; or, hey, maybe you just pretended you were awesome because you REALLY just live in wagons rolling around the prairies being terrible at everything you DO!)

where was I?

Right. The plot's not that great. The gameplay, well, it could be better, I suppose. The Fade is so bad, that people have modded it out, and Orzammar, once you head out of the city and into the caves beyond, is just awful.

...and yet I've beat it three times, played through the expansion, bought all the DLC religiously, and, despite all clear warning signs to the contrary, purchased a copy of Dragon Age II, which ended up being worse than a good number of people said. But its lack of quality is fairly self-evident--it's been said that retail chains refused to stock a GOTY edition after EA approached them.

So why do I love Dragon Age?

I dunno. It's certainly not because I'm a Baldur's Gate fan, as some have suggested, because I've never played Baldur's Gate before. It's not because of Morrigan, who, up until Fenris, was the most anime (and not in a good way) character the series had.

You might notice I'm bashing this game an awful lot, and I don't really mean to. The truth is that I just don't know why I love this game as much as I do. I have fun with it. I think the systems are deep. I've set up my team tactics so well that one time, when I forgot to pause, I left, and returned to find a boss dead. I've beaten the game twice as a rogue (when it comes to Bioware games, the hardest difficulty is Rogue + Hardest Difficulty, always), and experimented with other classes; what's fascinating is how differently both of my rogue playthroughs were. In one game, I was a melee archer. In another, I was a backstabber with grenades. I've discovered that the game isn't particularly fun if you roll mage--best to keep just one mage in your party, otherwise it kinda sucks.

I love the characters who aren't Morrigan or Zevran. No one is exactly what they appear to be when you first meet them, except for Dog, who is exactly what you would expect from a Dog who loves you unconditionally; this is a game that benefits tremendously from the player actually trying to role-play. Leliana isn't just a puritanical priestess. Wynne looooves alcohol. Oghren isn't just a boozer, he's a man/dwarf with a broken heart. Sten loves cookies and wants to go on adventures with you, which you'd never guess if you were intolerant of weird religions.

So it seems weird to say that the actual combat isn't super compelling, the plot itself is rather boring and just another Bioware plot, so it's nothing special or good. Plus and the main acts of the game are boring--the mage's tower's time spent in the Fade, EVERY SINGLE SECOND spent helping elves out, and the awful writing in Orzammar.

And yet I've put two hundred and eighteen hours into it, I'd willingly play through it again, and I know I'd have fun doing it.

I just can't tell you exactly why that is.

Enchantment! Enchantment!
Described as the spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate by former Bioware CEO Ray Muzyka, Dragon Age: Origins was easily one of the most hotly anticipated releases of the 2009 Christmas calendar. Party-based role playing games, which where immensely popular in the late nineties and early two thousands, had long since fallen out of favor with most big publishing houses thanks to the rise and popularity of the home console. With their lengthy novella like texts and lethargic combat mechanics (often involving a lot of pausing, lining up of abilities and buffs and strategic character placements on the battlefield) they were simply no longer du jour. PC piracy at the time also played a large contributing factor towards why most PC-centric development houses were jumping ship and abandoning the PC, so to the many fans of this genre of RPG we simply had to contend with the fact that party-based role playing games were, in all probability, dead in the water since they are often incredibly difficult games to replicate, without making the game an entirely cumbersome affair, on a home console, without the use of a mouse and a keyboard.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=400232207
Sadly the success of Dragon Age: Origins on the PC did not herald a second coming as the subsequent sequels in the franchise devolved into a more action-orientated affair. It would be another four years before we saw the genre gain popularity once again thanks to independent studios using crowd-funding and early access to breath life back into the genre (Obsidian's and InXile's Kickstarted Pillars of Eternity, Wasteland 2 and upcoming Torment: Tides of Numenera to Larian Studios early access title Divinity: Original Sin). Dragon Age: Origins is a great entry point for those unfamiliar with the genre or find the older classics upon which the game takes many of its ques (Baldur's Gate 1 and 2) a little too harsh on the eye or feel that they are a tad too outdated for the modern era. Once again Bioware shows its usual flair when it comes to world building which are often filled to the brim with a detailed narrative, fully fleshed out characters and an engrossing lore to anchor the world and give it a presence. Being a modern game with a far bigger budget all narrative is now fully voiced and accompanied by impressive cut scenes which drive the story forward removing one of the barriers to the genre - the tome like texts that were often used to drive the narrative forward.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=385314955
Where Dragon Age: Origins succeeds admirably though is through the origin tale it tells of the hero you select at the start of the game. There are a host of options to choose from depending which route you plan to cover at the start (mage, human, dwarf or elf) with each race getting its very own opening chapter which fleshes out the lore of each race wonderfully before dovetailing comfortably into the games main plot which sees your hero being recruited by the head of the Grey Wardens, a fabled group of warriors who must unite the Kingdom of Ferelden before an impending demon invasion know as blight tears the kingdom asunder. As with most party-based role playing games the canvas upon which Dragon Age: Origins etches its tale is broad and sweeping and filled with a host of memorable characters (although it is no where near as large a game as the classics of yore). As the tale progresses the player will eventually form a party of four from a host of characters that you, the leader, can recruit on your travels. You will always have access to them in your party even as the roster grows, each coming with their own strengths and weaknesses so it will be up to you to play mix and match until you have found a formula that suits you best. Like your main character you will also have a hand in dealing how each character develops over the course of the stories arc which adds nicely to the replay value should you consider to go another round after the main campaign is completed. While the party mechanic is filled with a host of well rounded characters my only gripe here is that you will need to micro manage your party right down to who gets to take a ♥♥♥♥ first because on any difficulty level above easy characters sometimes have a hard time obeying the commands you just gave them and even if you use the tactical slots given to you, which are unlocked the further you progress, they still often go off on a tangent and have to be quickly brought back into line lest the party forfeit the battle.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=385057627
If you own the Ultimate Edition - all DLC previously offered as in game purchases through the game client is included. Each DLC is its own self contained adventure that lasts roughly 2-4 hrs depending on your playstyle. None of the DLC is unfortunately up to the same level of excellence as the main campaign but completing either of them does include some valuable gear and equipment that can be used in the main game or carried over into Dragon Age: Awakenings - the full expansion pack that accompanies the Dragon Age: Origins Ultimate Edition. Graphically, Dragon Age: Origins has aged particularly well. It was never a looker to begin with but 6 years on from release they are still serviceable if a little brown, muddy and drab. Developed using the Lycium engine, this engine was eventually put out to pasture and replaced with the Frostbite engine for Dragon Age Inquisition. The game is also served by a fully orchestrated soundtrack which is hits just the right amount of epic during key moments of the adventure.

There really isn't much to fault with Biowares return to dark, gritty heroic fantasy. It is a real throwback to the good old days of RPG gaming and it enthralls and entertains at every turn and it is certainly in my top favorite RPG games of all time so I have no qualms recommending it as an essential purchase for all RPG lovers the world over. If you haven't given the game a spin yet or don't own it in your library I highly recommend you purchase it during the sale or give it a spin soonest. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
First, let's make one thing clear - I am the RPG Master. I suck at FPS, am mediocre at strategy games (at best), but when it comes to absorbing lore, story and fantasy world setting, I know what I'm doing.

Dragon Age: Origins is a game that tries to recapture the immersion and style of the legendary PC RPGs of yore, such as Baldur's Gate and Planescape: Torment; and it succeeds...somewhat. I have mixed feelings about this game.

First, the world and setting - the delivery is dark and beautiful. Most of the art and level design is fantastic, and the atmosphere is just great (including the sound assets and music). Some of the concepts explored, especially religion, is (mostly) maturely handled and gives the game a dark, gritty feel where choices matter and not everything has a fairytale ending. On the other hand, Dragon Age, as a new IP, gave BioWare the chance to move away from the tired old Tolkienen mythos with its elves, dwarves and orcs (Darkspawn). Dragon Age sadly did not grasp this opportunity, instead opting for the safe approach of classic fantasy RPG cliches. Just like every other franchise of Tolkienen origin, humans are common and varied, Elves are few in number and mistrusted, and Dwarves are selfish and suspicious underground-dwellers.

Despite this, Dragon Age has some outstandingly written and delivered characters (albeit one or two iffy ones as well), and the fact I can remember who they are in 2014 after buying this game in 2009 speaks volumes of the effort that went into creating them and fleshing them out. There's some great dialogue and banter between all the party members and the Warden, and occasionally with each other, some of which is truly memorable.

The main storyline, on the other hand, was a disappointment. The greatest RPGs build their plot around a link between a protagonist and antagonist, and support that link with supporting characters and a series of events that affect and change those characters. This is what made RPGs like the Baldur's Gate series, Planescape: Torment, and the PSX-era Final Fantasies so great. Dragon Age's main villain? Some sort of dragon/demon hybrid with minimal back-story (something about corrupted Tevinter gods based on an in-game myth and...nope, that's all there really is). Number of great villainous speeches and dialogues: zero. Reasoning behind bringing thousands of Darkspawn to the surface in the form of the Blight? No, I don't know either. All we get is some wishy-washy concept of the Warden being linked to the Archdemon by drinking Darkspawn blood.

There are so many things I wanted to know about the world of DA:O that could've been revealed through gameplay and/or dialogue - are the archdemons really corrupted Tevinter gods? Does Urthemiel (the archdemon) retain any semblance of true intelligence or decision-making capability? What was he/she like in the way of godly aspect or personality? Who is the Maker? Is the story of Tevinter and the Golden City true? What is the true origin of the Darkspawn? All these things remain unaswered, at most hinted at in codex lore that many players will not even read.

Loghain, on the other hand, was a character who deserved more screen-time and had a lot more potential as an antagonist. Unfortunately, despite his apparent intellect, he came across as too narrow-minded to be truly threatening or powerful, so again this was a story opportunity wasted. Overall, the story of Dragon Age: Origins spends too much time meandering about overly-long dungeons, collecting allies and items in what amounts to a series of fetch quests with the occasional bit of good dialogue. This part of the game should not have taken 50 hours and taken up most of the game's length, which demonstrates a lack of pacing in the storytelling. There's very little in the way of personal development for the Warden, such as discovering and unlocking your abilities as a Bhaalspawn in the Baldur's Gate series. When you're not dungeoneering or playing politics, you're doing tedious sidequests with insipid rewards like some errand boy - if you want sidequests or distractions, where are the optional superbosses, or high-end dungeons where challenging creatures and the most powerful weapons in the game are found? Lengthy but relevant sidequests that tie into the main storyline and/or character, like Firkraag in BG2? Not here, unfortunately.

All things considered, I've attacked Dragon Age: Origins pretty hard so far, so why am I still recommending it? Well, the game's mechanics are good, combat is visceral and satisfying, a lot of the character dialogue is really good, and the design of the world and locations, and the immersion they provide are excellent. You will lose yourself in this adventure for many, many hours and for that it's worth playing, especially if you can pick it up on sale. It's just a shame the core story had such a lack of nuance, and left me with so many unanswered questions.

reviewText: Having finished the whole thing more than 12 times, have to say. It is OK. don't be deceived by the 465 hours on record, most of those playthroughs were outside Steam.  Definitely do NOT buy the standard edition, but hang out for the 'Ultimate Edition' because there is LOTS of DLC and you want it all. Dragon Age Origins is something of an enigma. It is a great RPG that brought together most of the good things that Bioware had achieved with Baldur's Gate and the Neverwinter Nights games, but it falls just short of perfecting them. All the content is superb except for the absence of an explorable world, (something Bioware has never even tried to achieve). Sadly the series turned South after this. Edmonton seems obsessed with the idea that video games need to be interactive movies where players marvel at the studio's voice acting talent and cinematic cut scenes. They forgot along the way that role-playing is about the players creating their own stories. In time all of the once numerous class and race options that players had enjoyed with the AD&D based system disappeared, along with any real moral or narrative choices. Dragon Age Origins was the last Hurrah for the old-style feel. I would say that every RPG fan NEEDS to own and play the Ultimate edition of Origins. Enjoy all that is good in it. Also observe the key ways in which it fails. Origins is a great case study in RPG design.

Dragon Age: Origins is a role-playing game from Electronic Arts. Dragon Age: Origins is a story about a Grey Warden (your characters, the protagonist) from Thedas in a country called Ferelden. The country is under attack by dark forces. Your duty is to protect it from destruction.

Your choice in the game will affect your entire adventure and will also carried out to the next game Dragon Age: Origins - Awakening. This game is open-world so you can travel anywhere in Ferelden and you can choose which quest you want to complete first. Also, you're not going alone in this game, you're going to meet some companions on your way in the game, some are nice, some are not.

Dragon Age: Origins graphics are quite decent. The characters animation are good, each weapons can have different animations when characters attack. The effects and the environment in Dragon Age: Origins is also good.

Overall, Dragon Age: Origins is a good game and I recommend this for RPG lovers.

reviewText: If you're into RPG's, or rather if you love roleplaying in general, there's really no need to waste time reading any reviews of this game. The same goes if you regard games like Planescape: Torment, Fallout 2 and the Baldurs Gate-series among the best computer games ever made. Because this game is everything a person like you look for in a game, and so much more. Be aware though, Dragon Age: Origins is not a revolution of the genre, rather it is an evolution, where Bioware has refined everything that made them into a formula as close to perfection as possible.A spectacular experience from beginning to end, and with an enormous amount of choices to make, cities to visit, dungeons to crawl, NPCs to interact with, treasure to find, quests to complete and crafts to master, I feel pretty confident in saying that Dragon Age: Origins is, without a doubt, one of the most enjoyable and immersive RPG experiences I've had.Incredible storytelling, great characters, and exciting battles are just a few of the things that make this fantasy role-playing game so extraordinary.Dragon Age: Origins might have a few clichés here and there, but for those looking for a RPG to lose themselves in, you need not look any further.This is the most enormously detailed game world I've experienced, its history stretching back thousands of years, its cultures vivid, beautiful and flawed, the battles enormous, the humour superb. Roleplaying games now have a great deal to live up to.

reviewText:
This game is certainly my favorite RPG of the 2000-2009 era in gaming.  It built on the successes of earlier RPGs such as baldur's gate and neverwinter and really decided to make a gmae world worth exploring.

I've been playing the game every so often since 2009 and there are certain aspects of the game that don't hold up, like excessive pop-in texturing, long (and progressively longer loading times with larger save files) loading times even on PC, which is a sad, sad thing.  When one has a hybrid-SSD, a game should not take 5-10 minutes to load an action sequence.  Which leads me to believe it is a memory leak, or a fault in the programming, as this generally seems to follow a set pattern.  The length of the load-time increases in proportion with two variables.  The first variable is how long you have been playing the current character, and the second variable is how long you've been playing in the current session.

Also, random encounters are a crappy thing to do to a player.  Just look at every JRPG.  Did anyone think that was a good idea?   And...some of the animations are cheesy and overdone.

Okay, I got all the bad stuff out of the way first.  Everything else is completely masterful.  The art direction, music, combat/tactics, and story progression are legendary.  I have yet to find a game that has this massive of a scope and yet allows consequential decisions by the player-character/warden.

Even in 2009 I thought the Origins were an awesome addition, even if they didn't altogether seem to change the overall outcome of the game.  They were subtle and yet informative.  They helped shape a person's backstory, and also changed the way NPCs refer to you throughout the game.  I played as Dwarf Noble, Dwarf Castleless, Human Noble, City Elf, and Mage.  The only one I've yet to do is Dalish Elf.   I can't wait for inquisition to come out, since i have a Dwarf Female Castless rogue (warden plus warden commander and all dlc) imported to DA2, and ready to go for DA:I.

Mass Effect capitalized on the meaningful companions and meaningful choices formula, but DA:O took it to a new level (minus the whole gifts charade).  Each companion you pick up (and many of them aren't even required) are unique and interesting.  They interact with each other and with the world around them.  They respond believably to the events that your Warden gets into, and are all worthwhile investments of your time.  Get to know them.  Even Morrigan, and especially Alistair and Leliana.  They're all wonderful people that feel real.

In the end, though, what keeps me coming back to the game is that there aren't any other games out there like it.  There are some that have tried, but oh how they've failed.  I'm looking at you, Kingdoms of Amalur.  Even DA2 couldn't compete with its predecessor in terms of replayability and meaningful consequences.

It would be exceeedingly rare for two separate gamers to have two Wardens that made all the same choices.  I'd say the odds would be somewhere in the hundreds of millions to one.  There are hundreds of small choices, and quite a few large ones that not only affect the ending, but leak over into the DLC and Awakening (and somewhat into DA2).  This is what makes this game a masterpiece.  It singlehandedly makes you forget your life and brings you into the fold of Ferelden, Amaranthine, and Thedas itself.  Only the Bethesda games can claim to have as large a scope, but DA:O will always win in excecution in my book.

DISCLAIMER: This game is very much worth the asking price but please consider getting the Ultimate Edition instead with all the dlc for only 10 more USD. Getting it all ingame through bioware point microransactions costs far more.

Dragon Age: Origins is easily one of the best games I have ever played. No other game has made me actually care about the characters on such a massive degree as this game has. Combine the world class Bioware writing and worlds with a pretty good but not perfect combat system and you have truly an epic adventure to behold. The world itself isn't really open world but that doesn't stop the land of Ferelden from being an interesting realm to explore. Graphically the game is quite dated now and lip syncing/animations are at times awkward (oh god the sex scenes ._.) but there is a very large mod database for improving visuals and despite looking old the game is still very much playable. (Also I'm pretty sure anything can run this game in this day and age)

Having many important choices actually matter and have a huge impact on the story makes this game incredibly replayable and a wetdream for roleplayers. In many situations you can be the good samaritan or evil incarnate. This leads to a level of immersion  rivaling that of other high fantasy rpgs such as the Elder Scrolls games. Everything from the various dialogue/party banter for the smallest of details to your companions actually having opinions on every choice you make really sells Dragon Age: Origins as a living breathing believable world which you can get lost in for hours on end.

The combat is very traditional dnd/baldurs gate style combat which some people who favor tactical combat with many pauses will enjoy and those who enjoy something like traditional hack n slash may not. Also the game starts off very slow so you have been warned. It picks up a few hours in when your party actually has a variety of skills.

My playtime (5% being me alt tabbed out) is for a single playthrough so there is definitely a ton of content in this game.

reviewText:
(Note: I originally wrote this review on November 4, 2009 for a publication and focused on both the console and PC versions. I just updated it five years later in November, 2014 in order to update some of the references and make it more palatable for a gamer considering the title in the modern day.)

Most of the gamers that are going to purchase Dragon Age: Origins know exactly what they're getting into. They're likely to be either old school PC gamers with love for the Baldur's Gate series or a younger, fresher class of gamers that have enjoyed BioWare's more recent Mass Effect series. I'll preface this review by letting you know right now that if you fall into one of these two categories and for some reason haven't yet purchase this game, you need to buy it immediately, because you will be hopelessly enthralled by it. You don't even need to read the rest of this review. Just go get it. For those not familiar with any of BioWare's other games, or those who have played only more recent RPGs and enjoyed them, read on.

Dragon Age: Origins' most important strengths are the story, ambiance, and characters. Lead writer David Gaider came from a job in hospitality services to begin writing for Dragon Age years ago, but his lack of proper experience certainly hasn't hampered him in the slightest. He's brilliant. The world building is a particular strength; it's amazing, and the art team supports Gaider and his team's writing very well. Every structure has an apparent age to it, and everything feels well-worn. It doesn't just look like the structures and settings have a history behind them, it feels like it, and the game certainly helps out the feeling by providing a detailed history codex providing further detail on everything you encounter in the game. We're talking about a Tolkien-esque level of effort put into developing the lore behind this game. I was shocked to learn that I hadn't even seen combat yet in nearly two hours of playing the game simply because I was so engulfed in reading every entry provided to me in the game's encyclopedia. For gamers like me who enjoy this sort of thing, it's fantastic. If you ever feel bogged down by the constant codex entry notifications, don't worry, because you're free to go about your way without ever delving too deep into the historical aspects of the world, and the game doesn't at all punish you for neglecting it. Nearly anything you need to know by means of storyline will come up in conversation anyway. A realistic, living world is always nice, but the true value of this lies in how many different ways your choices actually affect this world. There's no good and evil meter to gamify and cheapen them, and your choices all affect the land of Ferelden in a very real way.

Another strength of the game is the richness of the characters. The nuances of your main character will be more or less shaped by you, and while that's a good thing, I would've liked to have heard spoken dialogue for my character rather than have him go the silent protagonist route. I thought BioWare did a fantastic job with how they allowed a healthy mix between player construction and static, unchangeable attributes regarding Shepard in Mass Effect. I wish they would have steered the main character of Dragon Age more toward that end of the spectrum. Aside from that gripe, the rest of the cast of characters are simply fantastic. All have deep, fully realized personalities and feel as genuine as a character from a great novel. There are no Vaans or Penelos in this game. Each character has their quirks, their strengths, and their weaknesses. The characters are so lifelike that you'll end up legitimately liking or disliking them after only a few conversations, and that's one of the real strengths of Dragon Age. It's all due to the fantastic writing done by Gaider and his team.

The gameplay is almost what you'd expect from a classic CRPG. It's very much like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, KOTOR, etc. If you're familiar with the combat in those games then you'll be able to step in to Dragon Age and feel right at home. If not, then you'll need to make a bit of an adjustment to this style of game. You can pause and micromanage, queueing up actions for your various party members if you wish, or you can set the AI to do what you'd like it to and let your party run on autopilot without pausing the action at all. At lower difficulties the game doesn't punish you for playing either way, though once I pumped up the difficulty I found it almost a necessity to utilize the pause-and-play micromanagement style. The way you choose to play will depend strictly on what type of gamer you are.

Make no mistake, this game was meant to be played on a PC. The graphics are absolutely atrocious while playing on a console, and it's obvious that the devs designed for a PC and then ported to the consoles -- A stark and unfortunate contrast to most titles nowadays. The graphical level of the XBOX 360 version of Dragon Age is equivalent to those of the first Mass Effect's now infamous pre-texture pop-ins. There is surprisingly little detail in the texture, and framerate has a terrible tendency to grind to a choppy halt at random intervals -- even when there isn't all that much going on onscreen. This, sadly, looks very much like a game that belongs back in 2005 or so. The PC, however, is very different, with much nicer textures and environments. The use of a hotbar and the tactical overhead view on the PC also favors that platform. The radial menus on the consoles are decent enough once you get used to them, but the hotbar is infinitely more effective, flows more continuously, and is far more comfortable to use. When you consider the amount of user-generated content available for this game in the form of mods, it's really no comparison. Rejoice, PCMR: This is a game created primarily for old-school, hardcore PC gamers.

There is, however, an issue to be had with the bugs present in the retail version of this game. Several times your character will get stuck on a bump or smooth rock on the ground, causing them to run in place continuously until you move them away manually. There's also an issue with your controlled character not responding to an attack command. Little things like this take away from the experience of an otherwise quality game, which is unfortunate, but now easily correctable with bug fix mods.

If you're a fan of BioWare's previous titles or old school CRPGs in general, this game has a very good chance of becoming an instant favorite of yours. It's not for everybody, though. Those who find RPGs to be a bit too slowly paced or plot heavy for their liking will probably be instantly turned away from this game. But if you can look past the faults of the game, there's a wonderful experience to be had with this title, and I'm sure I won't be done playing this for a long, long time.

In conclusion, this is a love letter to old school CRPGs like Planescape: Torment, Baldur's Gate II, and the like. If you liked those games, you'll absolutely love this one. If you're an RPG fan in general, it's absolutely worth a purchase, as the story, world building, and characterization is second to none. You'll just have to get used to the overhead, tactical style of gameplay.

reviewText:
Dragon Age: Origins is definitely in my Top 3 for favorite Bioware games, coming close to KotOR 1 and ME2. It definitely has some of the most memorable companions (imo). I don't usually like to do pros and cons, but it's hard to break down this game any other way. so:

Pros:
- Incredible story. You really can't find a better underdog story than this, especially if you go the City Elf route. Not to mention that this could probably compete with Game of Thrones with all of the scheming and backstabbing.
- Six unique backstories. Sure the general plot stays the same, but with six different introduction stories, the game becomes very re-playable.
- Companions. Aside from the dog that you'll probably forget you even have, your companions are very unique and interesting. From Alistair to Zevran, they all have a personality that is hard to forget. Well, except for Sten, but he's memorable in other ways.
- Engrossing. The first time I played this, I was so involved in the story, I could hardly believe it when I checked the clock and saw that 3 hours had passed like nothing.
-Content. It will take a while for you to finish this game, no doubt about that. I generally average about 30 hours to finish, and that's without doing half of the side quests.

Cons:
- Combat. Don't expect the combat to be very exciting. It's a bit slow paced, and you'll spend most of your time watching your party take their sweet time to swing their swords while you wait for their abilities to cooldown.
- Dungeons. A lot of the dungeons are really drawn out. You'll spend so long fighting your way though the quests that you'll probably forget why you're there in the first place.

Overall, I'd give this game an 8.5/10. You won't be wasting your money here.
So what do you say? Are you ready to join the Night's Watch (er... Grey Wardens!) and take on the evil White Walkers (er... Darkspawn...) to determine the fate of Westeros? (Crap, Ferelden, sorry xD)

reviewText: In an age of...\n\nEr, that is, in an age where old school CRPGs are considered dead to most big-budget developers, Dragon Age Origins stands out as an attempt to update - without replacing - most of the classic western RPG mechanics. Begun before EA got its claws into BioWare, it reflects what many of us loved about them in years past, and seldom see now. It's a big, literally epic-scale, slow-paced story heavy game with overflowing inventory and an original but not too unfamiliar fantasy world. reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game a lot. Probably more than I should have, and I think at one point my wife was jealous of the attention I gave it.

The graphics are kinda middling, which is kinda sad, considering how much prettier the Mass Effect series was. Also, though the game was marketed as a dark fantasy, the setting and story really doesn't seam to draw much from George R. R. Martin, but instead from another author with two Rs in the middle of his name. You lead a not-fellowship to wage a war against not-orcs, to finally defeat not-Smaug picking up multiple Nouns-Of-Gerund along the way.

The combat, however, is both challenging and fun. It can be played from either a pause-and-play tactical isometric perspective, or a more visceral, action-oriented over-the-shoulder perspective. Things become particularly interesting when you add spellcasters to the mix. Many players of Dungeons and Dragons, will quickly recognize the simultaneous feeling of glee and dismay of accidentally incinerating your compatriots with an ill-targeted fireball with just a little too large a radius. Friendly fire can be turned off, though, for those so inclined.

For me though, one of the real appeals was the apparent fluidity of the story and incorporation of choice as a central element. Gone are the melodramatic moral decisions of past Bioware games, where you are choosing between saving an orphanage or committing genocide. These are replaced by hard choices where both sides have merits and flaws. Also gone are the binary morality meters, and are now replaced by levels of loyalty/amicability between yourself and each of your companions. For every choice, it seems like it will be popular with some in your group, and unpopular with others, and it's not all based on some oversimplified alignment code, but more on each characters individual values and history, which you will have plenty of interaction and clues leading up to these choices, so you feel like you have some insight in the consequences. There may still be some surprises though. These choices will also extend to the beginning at character creation, and each character you create can have different origin stories which will have varying degrees of reference and relevence throughout the story all the way until the end.

All these choices do have a limitation however, by the time you get to the end of the game, you may notice that for the most part, the consequences of your choices are mostly cosmetic. Whether you chose one side or another in a given conflict, really only determines the look of the disposable units you get in a final battle, and the grand story arch is fairly immutable. By the time you may realize this, though, it has been a fun ride, and it doesn't really diminish the grand feeling of shaping your story, and being torn on certain decisions along the way.

Finally, if you opt to buy the dlc, I recommend avoiding the in-game downloader, it takes FAR too long and is very buggy. Instead visit the bioware social site, log in to your profile and download and install them from there. It's much faster and hassle free.

reviewText: Dragon Age: Origins is a role-playing video game developed by BioWare's Edmonton studio and published by Electronic Arts. It is the first game in the Dragon Age franchise. Set in the fictional kingdom of Ferelden during a period of civil strife, the player assumes the role of a warrior, mage or rogue coming from an elven, human, or dwarven background who must unite the kingdom to fight an impending invasion by demonic forces. There is no tracking of moral alignment, just party favor. The player will accomplish different goals depending on if they choose to be good or evil, but the decisions that the player makes in the process will change the game world accordingly – deciding who will become king, for example, and affecting nations, races and their places in the world. These decisions will also influence the companion NPCs, possibly causing an NPC to leave the party or even attack the player if they disagree strongly with his or her actions. Your character begins the game by completing one of the six origin stories corresponding to the race and background of the character he or she created upon choosing a new game; the choices are Human Noble, Magi, Dalish Elf or City Elf, Dwarf Commoner or Dwarf Noble. The origin story determines the biography of the character and how NPCs react to the player for the rest of the game. For example, elves are often viewed as second class citizens by humans, while mages are treated with suspicion and fear, while the human noble is treated with respect. While exploring Ferelden, Your character will be presented with the opportunity to partake in numerous side-quests to flesh out the Dragon Age mythology, acquire powerful equipment, and earn experience points. Potential companions who have their own special ability/combat specialties and back-stories will also present themselves and offer to join the player's quest. Overall my rating for Dragon Age: Origins is 10/10 it is probably the best RPG game I have played so far. There is just so much to do in the game apart from the main questline for example there are plenty of side quests available for you to play throughout the game as well as the game having a very long and a really interesting story that will keep you entertained for a long time. I really recommend this game it is probably by far the best RPG game out there in my opinion. So once again I really recommend you get Dragon Age: Origins because I am absolutely without a single doubt 100% sure that Dragon Age: Origins will not disappoint you in anyway!.

reviewText: The story has some promise, and there seems to be good depth to the core game, but the camera controls are really awkward for mouse and keyboard and gameplay is a bit messy (it's an unhappy mix of MMORPG, classic top-down and action-RPG mechanics). The game also starts to show the bad writing and poor motion capture that plagued Bioware all throughout Mass Effect 3 and The Old Republic; the characters' origin stories are uninspired social justice rants railing against humans/normality and cutscenes convey little to no emotion or life, for example. Characters are also very stereotypical: Evil is evil because reasons (or because they are normal humans doing normal human things which are or inevitably lead to evil), Good can do no wrong (as long as you are not a normal human), and every 'deviant' is oppressed to the extreme yet glorified and noble.\n\nI really like stories (such as Neverwinter Nights from old Bioware), so I will probably finish this game someday, but I cannot recommend it to anyone. reviewText:
This is the best game, ever. Each race has three story lines, and although you still follow the same main storyline, the starting stories give each version a different feel. I have put DAYS, nay, WEEKS into this game. I'm still playing it now. I cannot recommend this more highly, if you like RPG type games. I can take or leave DA II, but have high hopes for the third one, when it comes out. Everyone should play DA:O. It should be made Law. You should not be able to have a Steam account unless you have played DA:O right to the end, on at least one race/class/background, whether through Steam or EA or just a boxed copy of the game, played without attachment to anything else (as I did, first time I played it). PLAY THIS GAME!!!

On a side note, I see that it shows I've played an hour of this via Steam. I just installed it from the disc, on the first day it was out, and don't recall registering it with EA. I can say you get at least 50 hours of play each run through. There are 3 races to choose from, with 2 back stories, and 3 classes. I've played every version, background story, class, race - I estimate I have played a minimum of 450 hours - probably more, considering I have a few double played classes/races (one female, one male version)

The rogue is the best class, if you like being able to open every chest in the game. Warrior is best if you just like to go in and beat everything to death, although one of the main sidekicks makes an awesome tank. The Mage is a fun class to play, if you like sparkles and fighting from a distance (or healing).

reviewText: I finished the game simply because I bought it. I bought it because of the overwhelming hype claiming that this is one of the best RPG's ever made. Sadly, what I found was pretty much a hack and slash action RPG with, sure, lots of in game stuff you can read about the world, but the actual gameplay involves very little that isn't simply bashing through armies of enemies Diablo style. This is an okay game, if I could give it a neutral instead of yes or no I'd give it that instead. It's glitchy and on my i7 Windows 10 machine with 16GB RAM crashed several times even with affinity set to 1. Several of the quests bugged out and at times textures disappeared too. A lot of the battle sequences are overly long, yet not all that challenging, patricularly the final battle and the Fade part of the game. I had to force myself to continue several times because I simply got bored with clicking enemies to death and pausing the game a million times to micro manage each character. Sometimes the characters just stand there and get bashed in the head even though you give them orders. There is nothing original or interesting about the plot or game mechanics, it's essentially Baldur's Gate 2 with more fighting and bugs. I honestly don't know what the fuss is about, and in my books this game falls far short from something like Ultima 7 (which I still consider the king of RPG's) or even Skyrim. 5 / 10.

reviewText:
I know it says I spent 317 hours playing this, but I really just left the game running a lot because it's really boring so I'd have to take breaks and it loaded up slowly on my old machine so I just left it on.

This game is alright, I suppose. Nothing groundbreaking, some parts of it feel exceptionally generic, other parts are more interesting. Some of the party members stand out, particularly Morrigan, Sten, and Oghren. There's some royal skullduggery that you can take direct part in, but it happens only after a lot of rather tedious questing.

I think a big problem with Bioware rpgs these days is that they set you up for big decisions that don't really have that much of an effect, you can *kinda* decide what side you're on, but the end game isn't going to change. It's not as bad as Fallout 3 in that regard, but it's not great.

I believe your time is better spent with other CRPGs. This game doesn't do anything those don't do better. Consider some infinity engine games, I personally enjoy those a lot more.  I will concede, however, that the Dragon Age Awakening expansion is fantastic. It's the best Dragon Age experience I've had (and I did play DA:II all the way through.) If awakening was standalone I would recommend that, as it doesn't try to shoehorn you into a ham-fisted 'epic plot' and instead just does strange things. If Bioware was ever listening to me, I'd tell them to dump their 'main' plot and focus on the Darkspawn-Archdemon-Fade-Dwarf lore exclusively.

Origin's story is hella predictable. It's only specific quests that showcase some nuanced writing, particularly the stuff involving the dwarvers and the mages. Meh all around, in my opinion. I remember that this won RPG of the year over Demon's Souls in 2009 and that really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off at the time. I'm not so salty any more, but I'm still not sure this is worth your time. There is much better out there.

All in all, the first 30 hours were great, and this game was THE game that taught me not to buy near launch anymore with a few notable exclusions. So I did take good things away from this experience, it was all not wasted.

reviewText:
Steam really needs to add an 'in between' button for recommending games....

I couldn't help but feeling like I should be playing Neverwinter nights 1 or 2 instead of this the whole time I was playing. It just feels like a lesser version of them.

The combat is just dreadfull. You can either control one character at a time in real time, or zoom out and try a more tactical approach. The thing is, it wont matter which you choose as combat lacks any meat. Your decisions on the battle field bearly matter. I think the bigger problem lies with the leveling system and the skills. They are so basic and boring and offer little choice as to how to build a character. Chances are one rogue will be 99% similar to any other rogue. In a game like Neverwinter (Not the dumbass free to play one on steam) there was meaningfull choice to be had when creating builds and leveling characters. I would spend hours just thinking about different builds.

The battles often feel like a 'staring at healthbars until one gets to low so I pause and give them a health potion' over and over again. As far as I have seen so far there are no healing spells or really much support spells. There isn't really any interconnection between players at all.

So that leaves 2 things that would keep you playing. The story, and the character building/dialogue.

So lets start with the story. I still have a good 25 hours left to play according to Howlongtobeat.com so I havn't seen all of the story. That being said..... I dont really care if I do. Its not a bad story but its been done before and there isnt much new to it. Basically a bunch of bad people are coming to kill everyone and you are the only one who can stop them. So you go from place to place amassing an army to fight them. Honestly it feels like Lord of the Rings. Its not a terrible story and I didn't really mind watching/listening to it, but there isn't anything there to make it different enough for me to WANT to hear the rest of it.

Then there is the characters. At this point in the game I have unlocked 4 people. Again, they arent terribly written and do actually have some amusing and interesting dialogue. Honestly its the only thing that kept me going for as long as I did. However, your choices dont really have any noticable impact (at least not to the point I got to). There is a influence system in the game where characters like or hate you depending on your actions but aside from them possibly leaving if they hate you enough... there doesnt seem to be anything to it. There is a romance option but its just ends after taking someone to bed and doesnt actually change anything.

One of the issues of this system is that it is very easy to abuse. You can only have 3 people in your party at a time which I think is fine for combat but when you are in cities it creates a huge problem. Let me give you an example.

One of the first villages you get to has a merchant who has raised his prices to the point of extortion. You have a few options here. You can be on his side for some coin and drive off the crowd, persuade or intemidate him to behave, or do nothing at all. If you drive of the crowd Party member A approves of your actions and you gain plus 3 influence with them but Party member B hates it and gets -8 influence. If you persuade the salesman to lower his profits and sell at a reasonable price Party member A Hates it -8 and Party member B likes it +3. However! All you need to do is take either part member A or party member B out of the party and replace them with a character that doesnt care about this situation to get the outcome you want.

That is kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I think that it would have made the game MUCH more enjoyable if dialouge acted as though all party members were present. This would cause not only more interesting options, but it would mean your choices actually matter.

I would have also liked to have seen some situations where your influence with a character did something. Say for instance at one point in the game you and person A walk off from camp to talk alone at X point in the game. Then a bandit or something attacks you. Now depeding on your influence with party member A they would either push you out of the way to take the attack themselves (high influence), Fight the bandit after he has stabed you and run him off/kill him (medium influence), run back to camp to get help (Low influence) or even they planed the attack themselves and the steal some money from you and run off (Critical influence). Just an example.

I just cant see a reason to play this over something like Neverwinter Nights 2 which is an amazing game with great combat and what I mentioned above. Genre:
DAO is a third person RPG high fantasy adventure based mainly on the LOTR story.

Game Design:
DAO makes heavy usage of dugeon crawling. You will notice it in the form of swamp trails, forest paths, caves, and city roads. There is also the less frequent boss fight and more rarely a puzzle.  The game opening is too slow due to excessive use of (boring) dialogue and dragged out character introductions.

Sound:
The background music that supports the game is performed well for a game and is the typical orchestrated classical/folk styles, but the selection is very limited. All tracks are recorded in very good quality, but it gets repetitive too early in the story. Voice-overs and sound effects are also good qualtity, but again very limited in scope.

Story:
The main story is non-original and lacks emotional engagement with the game play. Your task is to
stop the Dark Spawn army from taking over the kingdom. This is a direct copy from LOTR dark lord Sauron's army, but there are dragons.  All the other races are there like mages, trees, spiders, elves, dwarfs. It even has the enchanted rings, but there are no hobbits.

Mechanics:
There is no quick travel which makes the game extra laborious. There is no open world, and maps get boring quickly due to repetitive events, and scenes. Game mechanics and HUD work well, but nothing special. The use of teamwork is exploited well, which was DAO only notable plus. Some quests in the game are not playable unless you download in-game DLC. You will only be able to learn this after selecting the quest while you are playing the game. My most enjoyable take from DAO was the selectable team members you use to achieve each quest.

Summary:
DAO is an average game in scope and entertainment. Your enjoyment in playing the game will be quickly overtaken by its boring repetitions.

reviewText:
One of the best fantasy RPG's ever made, without a doubt.

To mention some of the Pros --> It's an incredibly entertaining game, it has a very rich strategic layer when compared to other RPG's like Skyrim or the Mass Effect series (also from the same developer). The combat is fulfilling, fun and very varied, as you can choose to play different classes with completely different playstyles which branch out into different specializations with diverse results. The story is deeply engaging and full of content, the role of religion as an institution of society, idealism versus pragmatism, liberty versus security, the morals of war, among countless other topics, of which I'll spoil not a single one. Character interactions are very varied, some will want to talk your ear off while others will be much more introverted and demand a different type of interaction.

It's biggest and only Con --> The game is HARD as hell for beginners, sometimes a little unfairly as well since it has a learning curve that involves mastering all the mechanics and details related to combat and character leveling, even though the game allows for a lot of freedom even at the hardest settings, for example, my character is a rogue dual wielder and archer, a friend of mine plays a mage who is also an armor-clad greatsword-carrying warrior, both of which are perfectly possible even when the game encourages you to follow a more focused path. However, the game is still hard, start it on EASY because it's going to ask you to learn the mechanic and take them VERY seriously.

All in all, if you're patient and are willing to learn and strategize, you'll adapt quickly and have one of the most amazing role playing experiences ever made. Inmensely recommended.

reviewText:
It has a pretty high barrier of entry due to the complicated RPG elements, but once you get into it it is fantastic.  It is a fantasy adventure, thus far semi-open world (it might open up more, I'm not entirely certain yet).

The combat system is completely different from RPGs like the Elder Scrolls where you control your character's attacks and blocks and that's all you have to worry about.  Instead, it is a lot like Diablo (you can play the game with a Dark Souls style camera view for any non-combat sections but the camera should be top down like Diablo in combat) except you control all of your party instead of just one person.  In order to manage that combat, they give you a pause button which you will use to issue orders (will, not can, the game would be impossible without the pause system).

At first, I expected the pause system to break the immersion of the game and that breaking it would ruin the experience.  However, it doesn't really break the immersion too much and it adds a ridiculous amount of depth to the combat.  When fighting enemies, it doesn't feel like a dull grind.  You have to strategize positioning of your party members and coordinate timing of using abilities (which have cooldowns and other usage limits) and choose which enemies are best to kill first and which can be tanked until the end of the combat.  After combat, your companions heal so it's a bit like Pokemon in the sense that after combat you can stop by a Pokemon center.

The story thus far is engaging but I'm not far enough in to really give a fair description.  The graphics are decent for being a few years old and the characters only suffer from Uncanny Valley Syndrome a little bit (much unlike Oblivion where I felt creeped out by every NPC I came across).  So far, the characters are likable and have unique personalities.  But really it's the combat that's gotten me to write this review with only 6 hours logged.  It is too good to not recommend it.

Edit:  Now 44 hours into this game and it really feels like it's dragging.  When you level up a character, they never really feel much stronger and combat has become a grind in the past 15 hours and feels like it interrupts the pacing of the game.  The first 30 hours I found the combat engaging so there is something good about the system.  The story is pretty slow going considering the urgency of the events of the story which makes it feel disconnected.  Supposedly a journey across a third of the world map takes 2 weeks and I made that several times over to buy supplies for crafting between 2 dungeons".  It's a good game but there are definitely imperfections.

Edit No. 2:  After a 3 month break I'm liking the game again.  It still seems slow (especially leveling) but I've gotten back into the loot system and have done a few sidequests to get some nice armor.  If it weren't for the sidequesting I've done
date: I could probably have the story beaten in 50 hours.  As it is I expect around 55 to 60 hours as my completion time."

reviewText:
I would definitely recomend this game. Far better than Dragon Age II, it is a game with almost infinite replayability (If that's a word).
Pros-
Diverse Backgrounds- There are multiple different backgrounds and races. From a human whose noble family has died to a dwarven criminal, there are to my knowledge twelve distinct choices which influence your gameplay and choices later on.
Companions- The companions you meet on your journeys are likable and react to different actions the player commits. The diversity among races and backgrounds makes them feel more real and unique. On another note: This is a bioware game and [SPOILER Alert] you WILL end up banging someone.
Choices- Unlike some other bioware games (Cough cough, Mass Effect 3), the choices you make significantly alters the game. The choices you make are not always easy either. You may take a while making up your mind.
The Dragon Age Universe- The world is fascinating and at times hard to understand. The mix of cultures and religions make it very likeable.
Replayability- With the choices and backgrounds, you would be hard pressed to not be able to play 20 times with different gameplay. The endings, social interractions and gameplay styles differ, and about every thing else does too.

Cons-
Gameplay- The enviroment and combat are rather dull. This is however steriotypical of rps in this generation. The world is static and the combat is really boring until you find harder opponents, wih honestly takes awhile.

If you want to play an rpg this is the Mecca. If you want something with alot of exitement this may not be for you.
P.S. Awakening is pretty much the actual sequal. Its a full length game and is better than Dragon Age II. It is an extension of the choices you make in Dragon Age: Origins.

reviewText:
I really liked the game.

I never had time before (I like playing RPG's to it's full extent) so I took my chance to play it this year.

The graphics might be a little outdated, but I don't pay much attention to the graphics deparment, if the story is good enough. It would be fair to say that I had to start my game three times, being the third the one that didn't crashed my game, so I saw a glimpse of at least three origins.

The story is more than good. You have tons of lore, lots of dungeons (the Deep Roads are really big, though I've read before that they were impossible. They are not impossible, but it might take about 15+ hours for completion), and relationship development.

I had to admit that having and developing relationships not only favours your party members' abilities, but also is interesting to develop.

Combat: Well, having a tactical camera is awesome. Really awesome. Makes it easier to control all your party members, and making pausing the game an option, makes some battles easier.

But, battles are sometimes unproportional. You might sweep a boss easily, and be killed ten seconds later by a pack of wolves. So, be on your guard and save the game after every one or two battles.

Also, having in your characters ranged and melee weapons makes strategies come up easily. Even if you don't spend points in dexterity, makes your dwarf able to help instead of going into suicidal mode.

Tactics are good, when they actually work, other times they just get in your way.

In my opinion, this is a well balanced and inmersing RPG, with an inclination to battle tactics.. Glad I've made some time to play it.

reviewText:
Baldur's Gate 2 is one of my favorite games all time and this is a worthy spiritual succesor to the D&D classic. The storyline while not neccesarily original will keep you interested long enough, it helps that most of your companions are interesting in their own right and you have the ability to experience different conversations and reactions depending on the chosen origin.

Don't expect a spamfest combat system, this is a old school RPG with tactical combat, pauses, role creation, positional attacks everything is here and it's greatly rewarding for the meticolous player.
Now this game is not perfect, as I said the story is not very original and the graphics leave a lot to be desired with low res textures and boring flat colors and design even tough it's a fantasy setting. And while the combat system is very rewarding it suffers (like most RPGs) once you get more loot and to a higher level, battles become to easy.

All in al an excellent RPG and a must buy for any RPG fan, specially old school ones.
